subject: Method Chains, was Re: Testing private methods
msgSnippet: I also have the requirement that I don t have any test code in my production code.  This also means I don t change the code just to enable testing.
messageBody:
I also have the requirement that I don't have any test code in my
production code. This also means I don't change the code just to
enable testing. (Test-first design has resulted in better designs
without compromising the integrity of the code)

If you are reluctant to change your code just so you can test it, you
should consider #2, #3 and #5. With Reflection (#2), your production
code stays the same, the test code just modifies it at run-time to
install the Mock objects. With #3, the subclasses could exist
completely in your testcode. Your production code would remain the
same. With Dynamic Proxies (#5), the proxy is created at run-time so
your production code is never modified.

- Greg



--- In junit@y..., Matt Caswell <m.caswell@h...> wrote:
> Very interesting. It seems to me that you could use 1-5 in certain
> circumstances. However I think I would be reluctant to change the
way my
> code was implemented just so that I could test it, as some of the
other
> posts on this topic have suggested you should do. Option 6 looks
like it
> could have a lot of potential - I would think it would work in
almost all
> scenarios without requiring that you write your implementation code
in a
> specifc way. I agree - it definately looks like a fun thing to try
and do!
>
> Matt
>

> From: ghouston@i...
> To: junit@y...

> Subject: [junit] Method Chains, was Re: Testing private methods
>
>
> There are several was to get Mock objects into your production code:
>
> 1. Parameters
>
> As Mr Freeman shows, you use parameters to pass the Mock into the
> class that calls it.
>
> 2 Reflection
>
> If B is referenced in a field of A, you can use reflection to
modify
> A and replace B with it's Mock.
>
> 3 Mole Pattern
>
> Subclass A, and use the subclass to setup the Mock. [I call this
> design the "Mole Pattern"]
>
> 4 Strategy Pattern
>
> Use a Strategy design pattern.
>
> 5 Dynamic Proxy
>
> If the B is an implementation of an Interface, you can use a
Dynamic
> Proxy (new feature of Java 1.3b). The Mock would be an
> InvocationHandler, instead of a twin of B.
>
> 6 Classloader
>
> Use a classloader to load the Mock instead of the real class.
>
> ---
>
> There may be other options, but these are the ones I've heard of.
> Personally, I've used everything except #6. Options #1
(parameters)
> and #2 (reflection) are my favorites. They are usually the easiest
> to implement and understand. For #2, I've used the
> PrivilegedAccessor.java [posted by Mr DiIorio] to make the
reflection
> work simple.
>
> I've never seen anyone use #6 (classloaders), I think it would be
fun
> to try.
>
> - Greg
>
>
> --- In junit@y..., "Steve Freeman" <steve@m...> wrote:
> > RE: Method Chains, was Re: Testing private methodsAlternatively,
> > change from:
> >
> > public class A {
> > public void f() {
> > b = new B();
> > b.doSomething();
> > }
> > }
> >
> > to:
> >
> > public class A {
> > public void f(B b) {
> > b.doSomething(aValue());
> > }
> > }
> >
> > The test then becomes:
> >
> > public class TestA {
> > public void testF() {
> > A anA = new A(aValue);
> > MockB mockB = new MockB();
> > mockB.setExpectedSomething(aValue);
> >
> > a.f(mockB);
> >
> > mockB.verify();
> > }
> > }
> >
> > We have found that changing to a style where you pass behaviours
> around, rather than data, avoids things like subclassing production
> code in a test and pushes the code to flexing in the 'right' kinda
> ways. If you can figure out what to pass in and what to verify,
then
> the rest of the test usually falls out.
> >
> > Steve
